title: Derrick Johnson (cornerback)
text:
Derrick Johnson (born February 9, 1982) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="cornerback">cornerback</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a> in the sixth round of the <a href="2005%20NFL%20Draft">2005 NFL Draft</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Washington%20Huskies%20football">Washington</a>.
As a rookie, Johnson played in 14 games, starting in 5, recording 41 total tackles, 1 sack, 4 passes defended and 1 fumble recovered, which he returned a Marcel Shipp fumble 78 yds for a touchdown against Arizona, Oct 2, 2005 in Mexico City. 
Johnson has also been a member of the <a href="Houston%20Texans">Houston Texans</a>, <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a>, <a href="Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a>, <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a> and <a href="Saskatchewan%20Roughriders">Saskatchewan Roughriders</a>.
Early years.
Johnson attended <a href="Notre%20Dame%20High%20School%20%28Riverside%2C%20California%29">Notre Dame High School</a> in <a href="Riverside%2C%20California">Riverside, California</a> where he <a href="Varsity%20letter">lettered</a> in <a href="High%20school%20football">football</a> and also competed in <a href="Track%20and%20field">track</a>. As a senior in 1999, Johnson rushed for 1,990 yards with 39 <a href="touchdown">touchdown</a>s, and also had 586 yards receiving. For his efforts, he was the <a href="De%20Anza%20League">De Anza League</a> most valuable player as well as all-<a href="California%20Interscholastic%20Federation">CIF</a>, all-county and Small Schools all-state selections.
Coming out of high school, Johnson was a member of the "<a href="Tacoma%20News-Tribune">Tacoma News-Tribune</a>" 's "Western 100" and a PrepStar All-Region pick at <a href="running%20back">running back</a>. He was ranked by PrepStar as the No. 9 running back in the West Region and ranked 37th in SuperPrep's <a href="California">California</a>/<a href="Hawaii">Hawaii</a>/<a href="Nevada">Nevada</a> 152.
Post playing career.
Johnson took up coaching after his playing days ended, coaching at <a href="California%20Military%20Institute">California Military Institute</a>, <a href="Canyon%20Springs%20High%20School%20%28Moreno%20Valley%2C%20California%29">Canyon Springs High School</a> and then at his alma mater, Notre Dame. In 2015, Johnson led the Titans to an undefeated 14-0 CIF SS Northwest Division Championship. The team also appeared in a state bowl game, the first time in school history. After two League championships, Johnson would resign and ultimately take on an assistant position at <a href="San%20Bernardino%20Valley%20College">San Bernardino Valley College</a>.
